title: Research
text:
Xu, Y. & Runner, J. (under review).¬†Long distance binding option for the Mandarin Chinese reflexive taziji. [preprint]
Chen, Z., Xu, Y. & Xie, Z. (2020). Assessing introspective linguistic judgments quantitatively: the case of The Syntax of Chinese.¬†Journal of East Asian Linguistics.¬†https://doi.org/10.1007/s10831-020-09210-y. [link]
Huang, X., Lin, D., Yang, Y., Xu, Y., Chen, Q., & Tanenhaus, M. K. (2020). Effects of character and word contextual diversity in Chinese beginning readers. Scientific Studies of Reading. 1-21. https://doi.org/10.1080/10888438.2020.1768258 [link]
Xu, Y. & Runner, J. (2019). Memory Retrieval in Reflexives Processing: Evidence against the Local Search Hypothesis. Working Papers in the Language Sciences at the University of Rochester vol.¬†7. [link]

title: Research
text:
Talks
Xu, Y., Ringhoff, N., Coons, R., Fluellen, L., Eisen, C. & Runner, J. T. (2020). Immediate effects of non-structural constraints in anaphor resolution: evidence from visual world eye-tracking. Talk presented at the 94th Annual Meeting of the Linguistic Society of America, New Orleans, LA.
Xu, Y., Runner, J. T., and Tanenhaus, M. K. (2019). Gender effects on gender neutral¬†anaphor resolution. Talk presented at the 2nd International Conference on Theoretical East Asian Psycholinguistics, Beijing, China.
Xu, Y., Xie, M., Chen, Q., and Tanenhaus, M. K. (2018). Time-course of orthographic effects in Chinese spoken word recognition. Talk presented at the 8th China International Conference on Eye Movements, Nanjing, China.
Xu, Y., Tian, Y., Runner, J. T., and Tanenhaus, M. K. (2018). Gender effects on gender ambiguous anaphor resolution. Talk presented at the 8th China International Conference on Eye Movements, Nanjing, China. (Best Paper Award)

title: Research
text:
Posters
Xu, Y. & Runner, J. T. (2020). Syntactic and semantic structure in VP ellipsis and VP anaphora processing. Poster presented at the 33rdCUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing, Amherst, MA
Chen, Z., Xu, Y. & Xie, Z. (2020). Assessing the reliability of informal acceptability judgments in Chinese syntax. Poster presented at the 33rdCUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing, Amherst, MA
Xu, Y., Runner, J. T., and Tanenhaus, M. K. (2019). Gender Effects on Gender Neutral Reflexives Resolution. Poster presented at the 32nd CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing, Boulder, CO.
Xu, Y., Ringhoff, N., Coons, R., Fluellen, L., Eisen, C., & Runner, J. T. (2019). Sensitivity to Gender Cues during Anaphor Resolution: Evidence from Visual World Eye-tracking. Poster presented at the 32nd CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing, Boulder, CO.
Xu, Y., Eisen, C., Fluellen, L., Zhou, Y., Ringhoff, N., Coons, R., & Runner, J. T. (2019). Gender Bias in Picture Noun Phrase Reflexive Resolution. Poster presented at the 32nd CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing, Boulder, CO.
Xu, Y. , Eisen, C., Zhou, Y & Runner, J. (2019). Gender Bias in Picture Noun Phrase Reflexive Resolution.¬†Poster presented at the 93rd Annual Meeting of the Linguistic Society of America, New York, NY. [Link]
Xu, Y., Tian, Y., Runner, J. T., and Tanenhaus, M. K. (2018a). Gender effects on gender ambiguous anaphor resolution. Poster presented at the 31st CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing, Davis, CA.
Xu, Y., Xie, M., Chen, Q., and Tanenhaus, M. K. (2018b). Time-course of orthographic effects in Chinese spoken word recognition. Poster presented at the 31st CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing, Davis, CA.
Xu, Y. & Runner, J. (2017).Sensitivity to gender information in anaphor resolution: the case of Mandarin Chinese.Poster presented at the 1st International Conference on Theoretical East Asian Psycholinguistics, Hong Kong.
Xu, Y. & Runner, J. (2016).¬†Memory retrieval in reflexives processing: Evidence against the local search hypothesis. Poster presented at the 29th Annual CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing, Gainesville, FL.
Xu, Y. & Runner, J. (2016).¬†Locality effects in long-distance reflexive retrieval: the case of Mandarin Chinese ziji.¬†Poster presented at the 90th¬†Annual Meeting of the Linguistic Society of America, Washington, D.C. [Link]

title: Enhancing Academic Writing with AI Tools
text:
Academic writing can be a demanding task, requiring precision, clarity, and extensive research. Fortunately, a range of AI tools are available to assist scholars in various stages of their writing process. In this blog post, we‚Äôll explore some of the best AI tools for polishing academic papers and conducting literature reviews.


Polishing your academic paper is essential to ensure it is clear, well-structured, and free of errors. Here are some AI tools that can help:

Grammarly

Advanced grammar, punctuation, and style suggestions.
Improvements for clarity and tone adjustments.
Grammarly

ProWritingAid

Comprehensive writing assistant with in-depth reports on style, grammar, and readability.
ProWritingAid

Hemingway Editor

Highlights complex sentences, passive voice, and other elements to make your writing clearer.
Hemingway Editor

Ginger Software

Grammar and spell checking, sentence rephrasing, and translation features.
Ginger Software

Ref-N-Write

Offers phrase templates, a plagiarism checker, and a thesaurus to improve writing style and consistency.
Ref-N-Write

LanguageTool

Open-source proofreading tool for grammar, style, and spelling errors in multiple languages.
LanguageTool

Writefull

Provides feedback on language, grammar, and style, tailored for academic writing.
Writefull

Slick Write

Checks for grammar errors, stylistic mistakes, and other writing features.
Slick Write

PaperRater

Online tool providing grammar, spelling, and style checks, along with plagiarism detection.
PaperRater

Turnitin

Known for plagiarism detection, also offers grammar and writing feedback through WriteCheck.
Turnitin





Literature reviews are a critical part of academic writing, helping to frame your research within the context of existing knowledge. Here are some AI tools that can aid in this process:

Litmaps

Discover and track academic papers, visualize citation networks.
Litmaps

ResearchRabbit

AI-powered tool for discovering and organizing research papers with personalized recommendations.
ResearchRabbit

Connected Papers

Visual tool creating graphs of related papers to help explore relevant literature.
Connected Papers

Iris.ai

AI tool for finding relevant research papers and organizing your literature review.
Iris.ai

Meta (formerly Meta.org)

Research discovery tool using AI to recommend relevant papers and track research trends.
Meta

Scholarcy

Summarizes research papers, highlighting key points, and creating structured summaries.
Scholarcy

QuillBot Summarizer

Summarizes long research papers to help identify key points.
QuillBot Summarizer

Scite

Provides citation context and insights into how a paper has been cited by others.
Scite

Mendeley

Reference manager with literature search capabilities and recommendations.
Mendeley

Zotero

Reference management tool with literature search capabilities.
Zotero


These tools can significantly streamline your academic writing process, helping you to produce high-quality papers and thorough literature reviews. Embrace the power of AI to enhance your research and writing!



With the plethora of AI tools available, academic writing and literature reviews can be more efficient and effective. By leveraging these technologies, scholars can focus more on their research and less on the mechanics of writing. Try out these tools and see how they can transform your academic work.
Happy writing!
This blog post was generated by ChatGPT.
